dc:source.dc:abstract: Bardet-Biedl syndrome (BBS) is primarily an autosomal recessive disorder characterised by the five cardinal features retinitis pigmentosa, postaxial polydactyly, mental retardation, obesity and hypogenitalism. In addition, renal cysts and other anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract can be present. To date, mutations in 12 BBS genes as well as in MKS1 and CEP290 have been identified as causing BBS. The vast genetic heterogeneity of BBS renders molecular genetic diagnosis difficult in terms of the time and cost required to screen all 204 coding exons.
dc:source.dc:creator: Harville HM
dc:source.dc:title: Identification of 11 novel mutations in eight BBS genes by high-resolution homozygosity mapping.

evidence.dc:description: reduced score due to lack of WES to rule out mutations in other BBS genes.
reduced score due to lack of WES to rule out mutations in other BBS genes.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Bardet-Biedl syndrome (BBS) is a genetically heterogeneous disorder characterized primarily by retinal dystrophy, obesity, polydactyly, renal malformations and learning disabilities. Although five BBS genes have been cloned, the molecular basis of this syndrome remains elusive. Here we show that BBS is probably caused by a defect at the basal body of ciliated cells. We have cloned a new BBS gene, BBS8, which encodes a protein with a prokaryotic domain, pilF, involved in pilus formation and twitching mobility. In one family, a homozygous null BBS8 mutation leads to BBS with randomization of left-right body axis symmetry, a known defect of the nodal cilium. We have also found that BBS8 localizes specifically to ciliated structures, such as the connecting cilium of the retina and columnar epithelial cells in the lung. In cells, BBS8 localizes to centrosomes and basal bodies and interacts with PCM1, a protein probably involved in ciliogenesis. Finally, we demonstrate that all available Caenorhabditis elegans BBS homologues are expressed exclusively in ciliated neurons, and contain regulatory elements for RFX, a transcription factor that modulates the expression of genes associated with ciliogenesis and intraflagellar transport.
dc:source.dc:creator: Ansley SJ
dc:source.dc:title: Basal body dysfunction is a likely cause of pleiotropic Bardet-Biedl syndrome.

evidence.dc:description: RT_PCR of BBS8 was performed using renal tubular cells and skin fibroblasts from patients BB12-04 and -05 and their unaffected sister BB12-06—who is heterozygous for the mutation. We detected BBS8 expression in BB12-06 and an unrelated control cell line, but not in the two BBS patients (Fig. 1c), suggesting that the aberrant BBS8 transcript is probably eliminated by nonsense-mediated decay.

evidence.detectionMethod: Mutation screening in BBS8 was performed by DHPLC analysis using at least three melting temperatures for each amplicon, followed by direct sequencing of the variant PCR fragments as described previously
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This study was performed on a series of 128 families containing one or more patients with a diagnosis of BBS

dc:source.dc:abstract: BBS8 is one of the eight genes identified to date for Bardet-Biedl syndrome (BBS)-an autosomal recessive condition associated with retinitis pigmentosa, obesity, polydactyly, cognitive impairment and kidney failure. The identification of BBS8 gave the key to the pathogenesis of the condition as a primary ciliary disorder. To date, only three families mutated in the BBS8 gene have been reported. Here, we report on three additional families with BBS8 mutations from a series of 128 BBS families. Two of the three families have homozygous mutations and one has a heterozygous mutation. Mutations in BBS8 probably account for only a minority of BBS families (2%), underlining the difficulty of genotyping heterogeneous conditions.
dc:source.dc:creator: Stoetzel C
dc:source.dc:title: BBS8 is rarely mutated in a cohort of 128 Bardet-Biedl syndrome families.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family1_II:3

evidence.dc:description: score reduced due to lack of WES to rule out variants in other BBS genes. Variant is alters canonical splicing region.

Immunocytochemical analyses show that BBS8 co-localizes with γ-tubulin in HEK293 cells, also BBS4 in HeLa cells. In ciliated cells BBS8 localizes to the basal body in NIH3T3 cells and to both basal bodies and centrosomes in IMCD3 cells. BBS8 expression was also seen in ciliated cells such as spermatids, the connecting cilium of the retina and bronchial epithelial cells of mice. Expression of BBS8 was also most prominent in cilited regions of C.elegans.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ansley_BBS8_Expression

evidence.dc:description: This evidence was upscored due to the abundance of evidence showing that BBS8 is expressed in ciliated cells, as BBS is known to be caused by ciliary dysfunction. The authors provide this evidence using multiple cell types, tissues, and model organisms.
Co-localization and coimmunoprecipitation analyses show that BBS8 interacts with PCM1 and BBS4, two proteins which have previously been implicated in BBS.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ansley_BBS8_Interaction

evidence.dc:description: BBS8 ablation was associated with severe reduction of rod and cone photoreceptor function and progressive degeneration of each photoreceptor subtype, recapitulating the retinitis pigmentosa symptoms seen in human BBS patients.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Bardet-Biedl syndrome (BBS) is an autosomal recessive ciliopathy characterized by developmental abnormalities and vision loss. To date, mutations in 21 genes have been linked to BBS. The products of eight of these BBS genes form a stable octameric complex termed the BBSome. Mutations in BBS8, a component of the BBSome, cause early vision loss, but the role of BBS8 in supporting vision is not known. To understand the mechanisms by which BBS8 supports rod and cone photoreceptor function, we generated animal models lacking BBS8. The loss of BBS8 protein led to concomitant decrease in the levels of BBSome subunits, BBS2 and BBS5 and increase in the levels of the BBS1 and BBS4 subunits. BBS8 ablation was associated with severe reduction of rod and cone photoreceptor function and progressive degeneration of each photoreceptor subtype. We observed disorganized and shortened photoreceptor outer segments (OS) at post-natal day 10 as the OS elaborates. Interestingly, loss of BBS8 led to changes in the distribution of photoreceptor axonemal proteins and hyper-acetylation of ciliary microtubules. In contrast to properly localized phototransduction machinery, we observed OS accumulation of syntaxin3, a protein normally found in the cytoplasm and the synaptic termini. In conclusion, our studies demonstrate the requirement for BBS8 in early development and elaboration of ciliated photoreceptor OS, explaining the need for BBS8 in normal vision. The findings from our study also imply that early targeting of both rods and cones in BBS8 patients is crucial for successful restoration of vision.
dc:source.dc:creator: Dilan TL
dc:source.dc:title: Bardet-Biedl syndrome-8 (BBS8) protein is crucial for the development of outer segments in photoreceptor neurons.

evidence.rdfs:label: Dilan_MouseModel

evidence.dc:description: BBS8-deficient retina degenerate rapidly and the mice are mostly blind after less than 6 months of age. KO mice exhibited a significant degeneration of the outer retinal layers, as determined by OCT analysis. This increased loss of retinal thickness also corresponded to a rapid loss of visual function in mutant mice as measured via OMR. ERG response of the cones and secondary neurons after photopic stimulation remained stable over time in wild type mice, however, Bbs8−/− mice never exhibited a cone response.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Bardet-Biedl syndrome (BBS) is an archetypical ciliopathy caused by defective ciliary trafficking and consequent function. Insights gained from BBS mouse models are applicable to other syndromic and nonsyndromic retinal diseases. This progressive characterization of the visual phenotype in three BBS mouse models sets a baseline for testing therapeutic interventions.
dc:source.dc:creator: Kretschmer V
dc:source.dc:title: Progressive Characterization of Visual Phenotype in Bardet-Biedl Syndrome Mutant Mice.

evidence.rdfs:label: Kretschmer_BBS8_KO

dc:description:
*TTC8* was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Bardet-Biedl syndrome (BBS) in 2003 (Ansley et al., PMID: 14520415). BBS is a rare genetically heterogeneous ciliopathy, characterized by rod-cone dystrophy, polydactyly, obesity, genital anomalies, renal anomalies, and intellectual disabilities.

This curation includes four variants (three disrupting splicing and one frameshift) that have been reported in five probands in three publications (PMIDs: 14520415, 16308660, 19797195). More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be biallelic loss-of-function.

This gene-disease association is also supported by expression studies from Ansley et. al. showing that *TTC8* is expressed in the basal body of cilium, as BBS is known to be caused by dysfunction of primary cilia (PMID: 14520415). Co-immunoprecipitation experiments show that TTC8 protein co-localizes with PCM1 and BBS4, which are encoded by two genes that have previously been implicated in BBS. Finally, two *Ttc8* knockout mouse models by Kretschmer et. al. and Dilan et. al. show that absence of the Ttc8 protein in mice results in rapid and severe retinal degeneration as seen in human BBS patients (PMIDs: 30901771, 29126234).

In summary, *TTC8* is definitively associated with autosomal recessive TTC8-related ciliopathy. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Retina GCEP on June 6, 2024 (SOP Version 10).
